intro: Melientha suavis, commonly known as the sweet melilot, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its fragrant, yellow or white flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant grows as an annual or biennial herb, typically reaching heights of 30 to 90 centimeters. Its leaves are trifoliate, consisting of three small, oval-shaped leaflets, and it produces elongated pods that contain several seeds. Melientha suavis is often grown for its ornamental value and has historical uses in herbal medicine.
